head.title: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway

hedline.hl1: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway

abstract.p: Ross Gelbspan letter says intense downpour that crippled New York City transportation systems on Aug 26 was most likely the result of global warming; cartoon

block.p: The most likely cause of the intense downpour on Thursday in New York was global climate change (front page, Aug. 27). Numerous studies have concluded that early-stage global warming is characterized by altered drought and rainfall patterns, more severe storms and a measurable increase in intense, severe downpours of snow and rain.

The most likely cause of the intense downpour on Thursday in New York was global climate change (front page, Aug. 27). Numerous studies have concluded that early-stage global warming is characterized by altered drought and rainfall patterns, more severe storms and a measurable increase in intense, severe downpours of snow and rain.

The increase in atmospheric humidity, longer droughts and paralyzing precipitation ''dumps'' are what the current generation of computer models project as manifestations of global warming. It is time for the news media to stress the documented effects of climate change in coverage of events like Thursday's flooding.
